Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Consortium for the Science of Sociotechnical Systems Research Summer Institute 2019

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports junior researchers' participation in the Consortium for the Science of Sociotechnical Systems Research (CSST) Summer Institute. The consortium fosters trans-disciplinary research into the interplay of humans and technology in complex computational systems, bringing together scholars from intellectual communities such as computer and information science, computer supported cooperative work and human computer interaction, social computing and social informatics, psychology and sociology, organizational studies and information technology, and education and learning sciences. The institute is a way to bring these scholars together, providing expertise and mentoring in conducting sociotechnical research, opportunities for creating new connections and collaborations across disciplines, learning and assessing new research methods and approaches, and in general foster convergence-style research in line with NSF's strategic goals. The funds will support junior scholars who are in most need of these kinds of connections and mentoring opportunities, increasing both the size and the diversity of the sociotechnical research community and strengthening the research capabilities of individual members.

The institute will take place at Rutgers University in June 2019. Participants will be recruited through a number of channels, including the existing CSST network, discipline-specific channels for announcing events, and organizations dedicated to broadening participation in STEM fields. Up to 50 participants will be invited, with selection criteria aimed at maximizing diversity of fields, research topics, methods, institutions, and backgrounds, emphasizing opportunities to applicants from universities with smaller research portfolios and thus fewer opportunities for research mentoring. The institute itself will conduct a number of activities as part of this mentoring, including chances for participants to discuss their work with close peers and mentors, opportunities to develop new collaborative activities, and plenary discussions of professional development in the space of sociotechnical systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A trans-disciplinary community known as the Consortium for the Science of Sociotechnical Systems Research (CSST) draws scholars from intellectual communities such as CSCW, HCI, social computing, organization studies, information visualization, social informatics, critical informatics, sociology, information systems, medical informatics, computer science, ICT for development, education, learning science, journalism, and political science. Through ?CSST Summer Research Institutes,? along with extended workshops, pre-conference workshops, and other activities, this community of researchers from academia and industry has developed a strong focus on investigating problems and opportunities arising from the interplay of social and technological systems that span individuals, groups, organizations, and societies. New cohorts of CSST researchers meet annually for a rigorous summer research institute. Summer institutes bring together senior PhD students, junior faculty and industry researchers, and senior researchers from industry and academia to share ideas, define new research directions and provide one another with feedback on ongoing projects in their socio-technical systems research.

NSF Award# 1922868 supported the CSST Summer Institute in June of 2019 held at Rutgers University led by Institute Chair and PI of the grant Rebecca Reynolds (Rutgers University), in partnership with Co-Chair Morgan Ames (University of California at Berkeley) and a cohort of 20+ senior scholar mentors and 60+ post-doctoral and early career researchers.

The stated goals of the 2019 CSST Summer Institute were to:

  1. Foster a diverse cohort of new sociotechnical researchers who will form the next generation of sociotechnical scholars;
  2. Mentor students in sociotechnical domains to guide their work and research by having experts in sociotechnical science give advice;
  3. Encourage and support the selection of sociotechnical research topics and the use of rigorous sociotechnical research methods;
  4. Encourage interdisciplinary approaches to research by introducing students to work from outside their own discipline, discussing the value of different research methods, exploring publication and credit cultures of different fields, and introducing students to techniques and skills that support interdisciplinary collaboration;
  5. Illustrate the diversity and value of sociotechnical approaches; and
  6. Make participation in the Summer Institute a rewarding experience that encourages students and faculty to actively participate in their professional communities, including the CSST network and ACM SIGCHI.

Out of ~80 applications through peer review with over 20 past participants in CSST, we chose 60 participants, securing small seed funding from other providers in addition to NSF. Participants paid for their own transportation. Even with this cost for doctoral and early career researchers, we had 100% attendance among those 60 accepted. We created a thoughtful, responsive agenda covering themes that were of importance to the participants, while also hosting significant opportunities for the participants to receive direct feedback on their current research, from a world-class group of mentors. The gender distribution of majority women participants shows one way in which diversity goals were met for the event. Further, 31% of the participants responded with non-US options for ?country of origin?.

Overall, our project report highlights evidence of many ways in which objectives were met as positive outcomes for the workshop. Upon completion of the event we issued a post-event satisfaction survey to participants (N=47 for a 76% response rate). Both qualitative and quantitative results offer evidentiary support that participants? experiences were overwhelmingly positive. We batched qualitative results by each objective above to offer evidence in the words of participants for outcomes achieved. In addition, the Institute has led a group of participants to create a Slack writing group and online chat that meets persistently still as of today (1/20/20), involving writing feedback sessions, job market discussions, and professional networking and sharing. This option was open to all participants and the login was distributed across all, subsequent to the event, voluntarily taken up by some of the participants themselves. With successful 2020 fundraising, UT-Austin will host the 2020 event under Dr. James Howison?s Chairship, and carry further this ongoing decade-plus scholarly tradition.
